name: 1607_E. Robot on the Board 1
description:
The robot is located on a checkered rectangular board of size n × m (n rows, m columns). The rows in the board are numbered from 1 to n from top to bottom, and the columns — from 1 to m from left to right.

The robot is able to move from the current cell to one of the four cells adjacent by side.

The sequence of commands s executed by the robot is given. Each command is denoted by one of the symbols 'L', 'R', 'D' or 'U', and triggers the movement to left, right, down or up, respectively.

The robot can start its movement in any cell. The robot executes the commands starting from the first one, strictly in the order in which they are listed in s. If the robot moves beyond the edge of the board, it falls and breaks. A command that causes the robot to break is not considered successfully executed.

The robot's task is to execute as many commands as possible without falling off the board. For example, on board 3 × 3, if the robot starts a sequence of actions s="RRDLUU" ("right", "right", "down", "left", "up", "up") from the central cell, the robot will perform one command, then the next command will force him to cross the edge. If the robot starts moving from the cell (2, 1) (second row, first column) then all commands will be executed successfully and the robot will stop at the cell (1, 2) (first row, second column).

<image> The robot starts from cell (2, 1) (second row, first column). It moves right, right, down, left, up, and up. In this case it ends in the cell (1, 2) (first row, second column).

Determine the cell from which the robot should start its movement in order to execute as many commands as possible.

Input

The first line contains an integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 10^4) — the number of test cases.

The next 2t lines contain descriptions of the test cases.

In the description of each test case, the first line contains two integers n and m (1 ≤ n, m ≤ 10^6) — the height and width of the field that the robot is located on. The second line of the description is a string s consisting solely of characters 'L', 'R', 'D' and 'U' — the sequence of commands the robot executes. The string has a length from 1 to 10^6 commands.

It is guaranteed that the total length of s over all test cases does not exceed 10^6.

Output

Print t lines, each of which contains the answer to the corresponding test case. The answer to the test case are two integers r (1 ≤ r ≤ n) and c (1 ≤ c ≤ m), separated by a space — the coordinates of the cell (row number and column number) from which the robot should start moving to perform as many commands as possible.

If there are several such cells, you may output any of them.

Example

Input


4
1 1
L
1 2
L
3 3
RRDLUU
4 3
LUURRDDLLLUU


Output


1 1
1 2
2 1
3 2
prompt:
The robot is located on a checkered rectangular board of size n × m (n rows, m columns). The rows in the board are numbered from 1 to n from top to bottom, and the columns — from 1 to m from left to right.

The sequence of commands s executed by the robot is given, each denoted by one of the symbols 'L', 'R', 'D' or 'U', and triggers the movement to left, right, down or up, respectively.

The robot can start its movement in any cell, executing the commands starting from the first one, strictly in the order in which they are listed in s, and a command that causes the robot to break is not considered successfully executed.

The robot's task is to execute as many commands as possible without falling off the board; for example, on board 3 × 3, if the robot starts a sequence of actions s="RRDLUU" ("right", "right", "down", "left", "up", "up") from the central cell, the robot will perform one command, then the next command will force him to cross the edge.

<image> The robot starts from cell (2, 1) (second row, first column). It moves right, right, down, left, up, and up. In this case it ends in the cell (1, 2) (first row, second column).

Determine the cell from which the robot should start its movement in order to execute as many commands as possible, considering edge scenarios where the commands may run the robot out of bounds early in its trajectory, and explore each potential starting position to evaluate its merit in successfully navigating the board under the given command sequence. Your task is to find the optimal starting position that maximizes command execution without crossing the edge boundaries.

Input

The first line contains an integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 10^4) — the number of test cases.

The next 2t lines contain descriptions of the test cases.

In the description of each test case, the first line contains two integers n and m (1 ≤ n, m ≤ 10^6) — the height and width of the field that the robot is located on. The second line of the description is a string s consisting solely of characters 'L', 'R', 'D' and 'U' — the sequence of commands the robot executes. The string has a length from 1 to 10^6 commands.

It is guaranteed that the total length of s over all test cases does not exceed 10^6.

Output

Print t lines, each of which contains the answer to the corresponding test case. The answer to the test case are two integers r (1 ≤ r ≤ n) and c (1 ≤ c ≤ m), separated by a space — the coordinates of the cell (row number and column number) from which the robot should start moving to perform as many commands as possible.

If there are several such cells, you may output any of them.

Example

Input


4
1 1
L
1 2
L
3 3
RRDLUU
4 3
LUURRDDLLLUU


Output


1 1
1 2
2 1
3 2

The sequence of commands s executed by the robot is given, each denoted by one of the symbols 'L', 'R', 'D' or 'U', and triggers the movement to left, right, down or up, respectively.

The robot can start its movement in any cell, executing the commands starting from the first one, strictly in the order in which they are listed in s, and a command that causes the robot to break is not considered successfully executed.

The robot's task is to execute as many commands as possible without falling off the board; for example, on board 3 × 3, if the robot starts a sequence of actions s="RRDLUU" ("right", "right", "down", "left", "up", "up") from the central cell, the robot will perform one command, then the next command will force him to cross the edge.

<image> The robot starts from cell (2, 1) (second row, first column). It moves right, right, down, left, up, and up. In this case it ends in the cell (1, 2) (first row, second column).

Determine the cell from which the robot should start its movement in order to execute as many commands as possible, considering edge scenarios where the commands may run the robot out of bounds early in its trajectory, and explore each potential starting position to evaluate its merit in successfully navigating the board under the given command sequence. Your task is to find the optimal starting position that maximizes command execution without crossing the edge boundaries.

Input

The first line contains an integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 10^4) — the number of test cases.

The next 2t lines contain descriptions of the test cases.

In the description of each test case, the first line contains two integers n and m (1 ≤ n, m ≤ 10^6) — the height and width of the field that the robot is located on. The second line of the description is a string s consisting solely of characters 'L', 'R', 'D' and 'U' — the sequence of commands the robot executes. The string has a length from 1 to 10^6 commands.

It is guaranteed that the total length of s over all test cases does not exceed 10^6.

Output

Print t lines, each of which contains the answer to the corresponding test case. The answer to the test case are two integers r (1 ≤ r ≤ n) and c (1 ≤ c ≤ m), separated by a space — the coordinates of the cell (row number and column number) from which the robot should start moving to perform as many commands as possible.

If there are several such cells, you may output any of them.

4 3
LUURRDDLLLUU


Output

completions:
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple

def find_optimal_starting_position(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, int, str]]) -> List[Tuple[int, int]]:
    """Finds the optimal starting position for the robot to execute the maximum number of commands without crossing the board boundary.

    Args:
        t (int): Number of test cases.
        test_cases (List[Tuple[int, int, str]]): List of test cases, each containing board dimensions and command sequence.

    Returns:
        List[Tuple[int, int]]: List of optimal starting positions for each test case.
    """
    results = []
    
    for n, m, s in test_cases:
        max_commands = 0
        optimal_position = (1, 1)
        
        # Iterate over all possible starting positions
        for start_row in range(1, n + 1):
            for start_col in range(1, m + 1):
                current_row, current_col = start_row, start_col
                commands_executed = 0
                
                # Execute commands from the starting position
                for command in s:
                    if command == 'L':
                        current_col -= 1
                    elif command == 'R':
                        current_col += 1
                    elif command == 'U':
                        current_row -= 1
                    elif command == 'D':
                        current_row += 1
                    
                    # Check if the robot is out of bounds
                    if current_row < 1 or current_row > n or current_col < 1 or current_col > m:
                        break
                    
                    commands_executed += 1
                
                # Update optimal position if more commands are executed
                if commands_executed > max_commands:
                    max_commands = commands_executed
                    optimal_position = (start_row, start_col)
        
        results.append(optimal_position)
    
    return results

def main():
    """Main function to handle input and output."""
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n, m = map(int, input().split())
        s = input().strip()
        test_cases.append((n, m, s))
    
    results = find_optimal_starting_position(t, test_cases)
    for result in results:
        print(result[0], result[1])

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

from typing import List, Tuple

def find_optimal_starting_position(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, int, str]]) -> List[Tuple[int, int]]:
    """Finds the optimal starting position for the robot to execute the maximum number of commands.

    Args:
        t: Number of test cases.
        test_cases: A list of tuples, each containing:
            - n: Number of rows in the board.
            - m: Number of columns in the board.
            - s: Sequence of commands ('L', 'R', 'D', 'U').

    Returns:
        A list of tuples, each containing the optimal starting position (row, column) for each test case.
    """
    results = []

    for n, m, s in test_cases:
        max_commands = 0
        optimal_position = (1, 1)

        # Iterate over all possible starting positions
        for start_row in range(1, n + 1):
            for start_col in range(1, m + 1):
                current_row, current_col = start_row, start_col
                commands_executed = 0

                # Simulate the command sequence
                for command in s:
                    if command == 'L':
                        current_col -= 1
                    elif command == 'R':
                        current_col += 1
                    elif command == 'U':
                        current_row -= 1
                    elif command == 'D':
                        current_row += 1

                    # Check if the robot is out of bounds
                    if current_row < 1 or current_row > n or current_col < 1 or current_col > m:
                        break

                    commands_executed += 1

                # Update the optimal position if more commands are executed
                if commands_executed > max_commands:
                    max_commands = commands_executed
                    optimal_position = (start_row, start_col)

        results.append(optimal_position)

    return results

# Input interface
def main():
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n, m = map(int, input().split())
        s = input().strip()
        test_cases.append((n, m, s))

    # Output interface
    results = find_optimal_starting_position(t, test_cases)
    for r, c in results:
        print(r, c)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

def find_optimal_starting_positions(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, int, str]]) -> List[Tuple[int, int]]:
    """Finds the optimal starting positions for the robot on the board to execute maximum commands.

    Args:
        t (int): Number of test cases.
        test_cases (List[Tuple[int, int, str]]): List of test cases, each containing the board dimensions and command sequence.

    Returns:
        List[Tuple[int, int]]: List of optimal starting positions for each test case.
    """
    results = []
    
    for n, m, s in test_cases:
        max_commands = 0
        optimal_position = (1, 1)
        
        # Iterate over all possible starting positions
        for start_row in range(1, n + 1):
            for start_col in range(1, m + 1):
                current_row, current_col = start_row, start_col
                commands_executed = 0
                
                # Simulate the robot's movement
                for command in s:
                    if command == 'L':
                        current_col -= 1
                    elif command == 'R':
                        current_col += 1
                    elif command == 'U':
                        current_row -= 1
                    elif command == 'D':
                        current_row += 1
                    
                    # Check if the robot is still within bounds
                    if 1 <= current_row <= n and 1 <= current_col <= m:
                        commands_executed += 1
                    else:
                        break
                
                # Update the optimal position if more commands are executed
                if commands_executed > max_commands:
                    max_commands = commands_executed
                    optimal_position = (start_row, start_col)
        
        results.append(optimal_position)
    
    return results

    for _ in range(t):

        s = input().strip()

    results = find_optimal_starting_positions(t, test_cases)
    for r, c in results:
        print(r, c)

    """
    results = []

    for n, m, s in test_cases:
        max_commands_executed = 0
        optimal_position = (1, 1)

        # Iterate over all possible starting positions
        for start_row in range(1, n + 1):
            for start_col in range(1, m + 1):
                current_row, current_col = start_row, start_col
                commands_executed = 0

                # Simulate the command sequence
                for command in s:
                    if command == 'L':
                        current_col -= 1
                    elif command == 'R':
                        current_col += 1
                    elif command == 'U':
                        current_row -= 1
                    elif command == 'D':
                        current_row += 1

                    # Check if the robot is out of bounds

                        break

                    commands_executed += 1

                # Update the optimal position if more commands are executed
                if commands_executed > max_commands_executed:
                    max_commands_executed = commands_executed
                    optimal_position = (start_row, start_col)

        results.append(optimal_position)

    return results

def find_optimal_start(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, int, str]]) -> List[Tuple[int, int]]:
    """Finds the optimal starting position for the robot to execute the maximum number of commands.

    Args:
        t (int): Number of test cases.
        test_cases (List[Tuple[int, int, str]]): List of test cases, each containing the board dimensions and command sequence.

    Returns:
        List[Tuple[int, int]]: List of optimal starting positions for each test case.
    """
    results = []

    for n, m, s in test_cases:
        max_commands_executed = 0
        optimal_start = (1, 1)

        # Iterate over all possible starting positions
        for start_row in range(1, n + 1):
            for start_col in range(1, m + 1):
                current_row, current_col = start_row, start_col
                commands_executed = 0

                # Simulate the robot's movement
                for command in s:
                    if command == 'L':
                        current_col -= 1
                    elif command == 'R':
                        current_col += 1
                    elif command == 'U':
                        current_row -= 1
                    elif command == 'D':
                        current_row += 1

                    # Check if the robot is still within the board boundaries
                    if 1 <= current_row <= n and 1 <= current_col <= m:
                        commands_executed += 1
                    else:
                        break

                # Update the optimal start position if more commands are executed
                if commands_executed > max_commands_executed:
                    max_commands_executed = commands_executed
                    optimal_start = (start_row, start_col)

        results.append(optimal_start)

    return results

def main():
    """Main function to handle input and output."""
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n, m = map(int, input().split())
        s = input().strip()
        test_cases.append((n, m, s))

    results = find_optimal_start(t, test_cases)
    for r, c in results:
        print(r, c)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

        # Initialize variables to track the optimal starting position
        max_commands_executed = 0

            for start_col in range(1, m + 1):
                current_row, current_col = start_row, start_col
                commands_executed = 0

                        current_col += 1
                    elif command == 'U':

                        current_row += 1

                        commands_executed += 1
                    else:
                        break

                # Update the optimal starting position if more commands are executed
                if commands_executed > max_commands_executed:
                    max_commands_executed = commands_executed
                    optimal_start_position = (start_row, start_col)

        results.append(optimal_start_position)

    return results

from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple

def find_optimal_starting_position(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, int, str]]) -> List[Tuple[int, int]]:
    """Finds the optimal starting position for the robot to execute the maximum number of commands.

    Args:
        t (int): Number of test cases.
        test_cases (List[Tuple[int, int, str]]): A list of test cases, each containing:
            - n (int): Number of rows in the board.
            - m (int): Number of columns in the board.
            - s (str): Sequence of commands.

    Returns:
        List[Tuple[int, int]]: A list of tuples, each containing the optimal starting row and column.
    """
    results = []

    for n, m, s in test_cases:
        # Initialize variables to track the best starting position
        max_commands_executed = 0
        best_start_row = 1
        best_start_col = 1

        # Iterate over all possible starting positions
        for start_row in range(1, n + 1):
            for start_col in range(1, m + 1):
                # Simulate the robot's movement from the current starting position
                current_row, current_col = start_row, start_col
                commands_executed = 0

                for command in s:
                    if command == 'L':
                        current_col -= 1
                    elif command == 'R':
                        current_col += 1
                    elif command == 'U':
                        current_row -= 1
                    elif command == 'D':
                        current_row += 1

                    # Check if the robot is still within bounds
                    if 1 <= current_row <= n and 1 <= current_col <= m:
                        commands_executed += 1
                    else:
                        break

                # Update the best starting position if more commands are executed
                if commands_executed > max_commands_executed:
                    max_commands_executed = commands_executed
                    best_start_row = start_row
                    best_start_col = start_col

        results.append((best_start_row, best_start_col))

    return results

def main():
    """Main function to handle input and output."""
    t = int(input().strip())
    test_cases = []

    for _ in range(t):
        n, m = map(int, input().strip().split())
        s = input().strip()
        test_cases.append((n, m, s))

    results = find_optimal_starting_position(t, test_cases)

    for r, c in results:
        print(r, c)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

from typing import List, Tuple

def find_optimal_starting_position(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, int, str]]) -> List[Tuple[int, int]]:
    """Finds the optimal starting position for the robot on the board to execute the maximum number of commands.

    Args:
        t (int): Number of test cases.
        test_cases (List[Tuple[int, int, str]]): A list of tuples where each tuple contains:
            - n (int): Number of rows in the board.
            - m (int): Number of columns in the board.
            - s (str): Sequence of commands.

    Returns:
        List[Tuple[int, int]]: A list of tuples where each tuple contains the optimal starting position (row, column).
    """
    results = []

    for n, m, s in test_cases:
        # Initialize variables to track the best starting position
        max_commands_executed = 0
        best_starting_position = (1, 1)

        # Iterate over all possible starting positions
        for start_row in range(1, n + 1):
            for start_col in range(1, m + 1):
                # Simulate the robot's movement from the current starting position
                current_row, current_col = start_row, start_col
                commands_executed = 0

                for command in s:
                    if command == 'L':
                        current_col -= 1
                    elif command == 'R':
                        current_col += 1
                    elif command == 'U':
                        current_row -= 1
                    elif command == 'D':
                        current_row += 1

                    # Check if the robot is still on the board
                    if 1 <= current_row <= n and 1 <= current_col <= m:
                        commands_executed += 1
                    else:
                        break

                # Update the best starting position if more commands are executed
                if commands_executed > max_commands_executed:
                    max_commands_executed = commands_executed
                    best_starting_position = (start_row, start_col)

        results.append(best_starting_position)

    return results

# Input interface
def main():
    t = int(input().strip())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n, m = map(int, input().strip().split())
        s = input().strip()
        test_cases.append((n, m, s))

    # Call the function
    results = find_optimal_starting_position(t, test_cases)

    # Output interface
    for result in results:
        print(result[0], result[1])

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

The function will track the number of commands executed before the robot would fall off the board. examples:
Input

The first line contains an integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 10^4) — the number of test cases.

The next 2t lines contain descriptions of the test cases.

In the description of each test case, the first line contains two integers n and m (1 ≤ n, m ≤ 10^6) — the height and width of the field that the robot is located on. The second line of the description is a string s consisting solely of characters 'L', 'R', 'D' and 'U' — the sequence of commands the robot executes. The string has a length from 1 to 10^6 commands.

It is guaranteed that the total length of s over all test cases does not exceed 10^6.

Output

Print t lines, each of which contains the answer to the corresponding test case. The answer to the test case are two integers r (1 ≤ r ≤ n) and c (1 ≤ c ≤ m), separated by a space — the coordinates of the cell (row number and column number) from which the robot should start moving to perform as many commands as possible.

If there are several such cells, you may output any of them.

Example

Input


4
1 1
L
1 2
L
3 3
RRDLUU
4 3
LUURRDDLLLUU


Output


1 1
1 2
2 1
3 2
